df.set_index('idx', inplace=True)

# New df for Examples
df
A B C D
idx
a A1 B1 C1 5
b A2 B2 C2 10
c A3 B3 C3 15
d A4 B4 C4 20
e A5 B5 C5 25

Passing a single argument to .loc and .iloc will select corresponding rows

# Can be a list of row indexes
df.loc[['a', 'b', 'c']]
A B C D
idx
a A1 B1 C1 5
b A2 B2 C2 10
c A3 B3 C3 15 
# Can also be a slice
# When the index is sorted all values between start and stop will be selected
df.loc['a':'c']
A B C D
idx
a A1 B1 C1 5
b A2 B2 C2 10
c A3 B3 C3 15

Notice that providing a range of indexes, UNLIKE prior slicing will include the stop value

# The above operations can also be carried out with iloc
df.iloc[[0, 1, 2]]
A B C D
idx
a A1 B1 C1 5
b A2 B2 C2 10
c A3 B3 C3 15 
df.iloc[0:3]
A B C D
idx
a A1 B1 C1 5
b A2 B2 C2 10
c A3 B3 C3 15

Passing two argument to .loc and .iloc allows for indexing and slicing by both rows and columns [rows, columns].

df.loc['a':'c', ['B', 'D']]
B D
idx
a B1 5
b B2 10
c B3 15 
df.iloc[:3, [1, 3]]
B D
idx
a B1 5
b B2 10
c B3 15

Both .loc and .iloc also allow for boolean indexing to return a subset of the DataFrame where the boolean expression evaluates to True

df.loc[df['D'] >= 15]
A B C D
idx
c A3 B3 C3 15
d A4 B4 C4 20
e A5 B5 C5 25 
# Showing the boolean mask shows that is is a Series with an index
bool_mask = df['D'] >= 15
bool_mask

idx
a    False
b    False
c     True
d     True
e     True
Name: D, dtype: bool

Using the mask directly will cause an error if used with .iloc. Remember .iloc is intended only for integer-location selection. To use with .iloc the boolean vector must be passed in.

# Boolean Vector
bool_mask.values

array([False, False,  True,  True,  True])
df.iloc[bool_mask.values]
A B C D
idx
c A3 B3 C3 15
d A4 B4 C4 20
e A5 B5 C5 25

Multiple boolean expression can be applied.

condition_1 = df['D'] >= 15
condition_2 = df['A'] == 'A1'
# Condition 1 OR Condition 2
df.loc[condition_1 | condition_2]
A B C D
idx
a A1 B1 C1 5
c A3 B3 C3 15
d A4 B4 C4 20
e A5 B5 C5 25 
df.loc[condition_1 | condition_2, 'A':'C']
A B C
idx
a A1 B1 C1
c A3 B3 C3
d A4 B4 C4
e A5 B5 C5

Summary


Pandas offers a multitude of options for selecting, indexing, and slicing DataFrame options. This articles provided an introduction to the .loc method for label based selecting, the .iloc method for integer-location based selecting as well as using the indexing operator [] whose behavior can depend on the index and arguments provided. Due to this confusion could be possible and the use of .loc and .iloc might be preferable.



If you enjoy what you read and find it helpful please check back, and check back often. Follow me on Medium while giving a clap to the article! Also don't forget to subscribe to the INQUISITIVE NATURE publication.

entry.title: Pandas: Data Transformation
entry.content:
Contents

  • Handling of Missing Data
    • Missing Data in Pandas
    • Null Value Operations
  • Transforming Data
    • Sorting DataFrame Value
    • Add Columns / Rows
    • Remove Columns / Rows
  • Aggregating DataFrames
    • Descriptive Statistics
  • Grouped Summary Statistics
    • Pivot Table
  • Joining DataFrames

Pandas is a data analysis and manipulation library which provides three fundamental data structures: Index, Series, and DataFrame. For more details on the data structures and an overview of the pandas library see the previous article - Pandas: Introduction to the Library.

The focus of this article is to service as a introduction and guide to the basic functions for modifying and manipulating the core data structures, including handling of missing data, DataFrame transformation, aggregating data, and joining DataFrames.


Handling of Missing Data


Datasets are typically not clean and ready for use, including that they may contain some level of missing data. How missing data is indicated can vary depending on the data source which can add an additional level of complication when handling the missing data.

Generally, there is no single optimal choice when developing a scheme to indicate the presence of missing data in a data table. Typically the schemes center around using a mask that indicates missing values or implementing a sentinel value that indicates a missing value.


Missing Data in Pandas

Within Pandas missing data is indicated by one of the two Python null values: NaN (Not a Number) indicating a missing floating-point value or the None object, and pandas can convert between the two when needed.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

series_1 = pd.Series([10, np.nan, 15, None])
series_1

0    10.0
1     NaN
2    15.0
3     NaN
dtype: float64

For types that do not have a sentinel value (e.g. integer) Pandas automatically type-casts when a missing value is present (e.g. cast an integer to a floating point)

series_2 = pd.Series([0, 1, 2])
series_2

0    0
1    1
2    2
dtype: int64
series_2[1] = None
series_2

0    0.0
1    NaN
2    2.0
dtype: float64

Missing values will propagate through arithmetic operations between pandas objects. Descriptive statistics and certain computational methods (Series and DataFrame) all account for missing data (e.g. when summing data missing values will be treated as zero).


Null Value Operations

Pandas offer various methods for identifying, removing, and replacing missing values within the data structures.

Identifying Null or Missing Values

pandas.isna(obj)

  • A function that takes a scalar or array-like object and is used to indicate whether there are missing values.
  • Returns a scalar or array of boolean values indicating whether each element is missing
pd.isna('string')

False
pd.isna(np.nan)

True
series = pd.Series([2, 4, np.nan, 8])
pd.isna(series)

0    False
1    False
2     True
3    False
dtype: bool

Series.isna()
DataFrame.isna()

  • A function used to identify missing values within a Series or DataFrame
  • Returns a boolean same-sized object indicating whether an element is a missing value
    • None or NaN get mapped to True and everything else is mapped to False
  • .isnull() is an alias for .isna()
  • .notna() performs the opposite operation of .isna()
    • Non-missing values get mapped to True
  • Boolean masks, like the object returned by isna(), can be used directly as a Series or DataFrame index
    • For more detail see: Pandas: Indexing and Slicing

Characters such as an empty string ' ' or np.inf are not considered missing values unless pandas.options.mod.use_inf_as_na = True is set

# Series Examples
even_series = pd.Series([2, None, 6, np.nan, 10])
even_series.isna()

0    False
1     True
2    False
3     True
4    False
dtype: bool
df = pd.DataFrame({'name':['Oliver', 'John', 'Jane', 'Ashley', 'Steve'],
                    'A':[71, 63, 86, 98, 75],
                    'B':[83, np.nan, 91, 99, 77],
                    'C':[np.nan, 87, 92, 79, 82],
                    'D':[88, 77, 78, 60, np.nan]})
# Example DataFrame
df
name A B C D
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 
df.isna()
name A B C D
0 False False False True False
1 False False True False False
2 False False False False False
3 False False False False False
4 False False False False True 
# DataFrame - Determine if an element is NOT missing a value
# (opposite of .isna())
df.notna()
name A B C D
0 True True True False True
1 True True False True True
2 True True True True True
3 True True True True True
4 True True True True False

Removing Null or Missing Values

Series.dropna(axis=0, inplace=False, how=None)

  • A function that returns a new series with missing values removed
    • axis (0 or 'index'): a Series has only one axis to drop values from
    • inplace (bool): if True the operation of removing missing values is done inplace and .dropna() returns None
    • how (str): not currently in use and is kept for compatibility
# Example Series
series = df['B']
series

0    83.0
1     NaN
2    91.0
3    99.0
4    77.0
Name: B, dtype: float64
# Default arguments
series.dropna()

0    83.0
2    91.0
3    99.0
4    77.0
Name: B, dtype: float64
# Reprinting the series verifies that the series has not 
# been modified
series

0    83.0
1     NaN
2    91.0
3    99.0
4    77.0
Name: B, dtype: float64
# Set inplace=True to complete teh operation inplace
series.dropna(inplace=True)
series

0    83.0
2    91.0
3    99.0
4    77.0
Name: B, dtype: float64

DataFrame.dropna(axis=0, how='any', thresh=None, subset=None, inplace=False)

  • axis {0/'index' or 1/'column'}: determine if missing values are removed from rows or columns
    • 0: drop rows that contain missing values
    • 1: drop columns that contain missing values
  • how {'any', 'all'}: determines if a row or column is removed when there is at least one missing value or all missing values
  • thresh (int): specify the number of non-missing values required to drop a row or column
  • subset (column or sequence labels): labels along an other axis (e.g. when dropping rows a list of columns to consider)
  • inplace (bool): boolean value, if True the operation of removing missing values is done inplace and returns None

Dropping missing values from a DataFrame operates on an entire row or column, a single missing value cannot be dropped

# DataFrame Example
df
name A B C D
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 
# Default: Drop all rows with any missing values
df.dropna()
name A B C D
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 
# Set axis=1 to drop all columns with missing values
df.dropna(axis=1)
name A
0 Oliver 71
1 John 63
2 Jane 86
3 Ashley 98
4 Steve 75 
# Set how keyword to drop only row/columns where all values are missing
df['F']=np.nan
df
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 NaN
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 NaN
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN 
df.dropna(axis='columns', how='all')
name A B C D
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 
# Set thresh keyword to specify the minimum number of non-missing values
df['F'] = [79, np.nan, 88, np.nan, np.nan]
df
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN 
df.dropna(axis='columns', thresh=3)
name A B C D
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN

Filling Null or Missing Values

Series.fillna(value=None, method=None, axis=None, inplace=False, limit=None, downcast=None) DataFrame.fillna(value=None, method=None, axis=None, inplace=False, limit=None, downcast=None)

  • value (scalar, dict, Series, DataFrame): the value used to replace missing values. Passing in a dict/Series/DataFrame of values specifying which value to use for each index (for a Series), or column (for a DataFrame), values not in the dict/Series/DataFrame will not be replaced
  • method {'backfill', 'bfill', 'pad', 'ffill', None}: the method used for replacing missing values in the reindexed series
    • pad/ffill: propagate the last valid observation forward to the next
    • backfill/bfill: uses the next valid observation to replace missing values
  • axis: the axis to replace missing values
    • 0 or 'index' for a Series
    • 0/'index' or 1/'column' for a DataFrame
  • inplace (bool): boolean value, if True the operation of removing missing values is done inplace and returns None
  • limit (int):
    • If method is specified, limit sets the maximum number of consecutive missing values to forward or backwards fill
    • If method is not specified, limit sets the maximum number of missing values along the entire axis that will be filled
  • downcast (dict): a dictionary of item->dtype of what downcast or string 'infer' which will try to downcast to an appropriate equal type
# Example DataFrame
df
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN 
# Basic fill methods
df.fillna(value=0)
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 0.0 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 0.0 87.0 77.0 0.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 0.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 0.0 0.0 
# Fill NaN using the backfill method - If the last value is NaN it will remain NaN
df.fillna(method='bfill')
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 87.0 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 91.0 87.0 77.0 88.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN 
# Fill Nan using the forwardfill method - If the first value is NaN it will remain NaN
df.fillna(method='ffill')
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 83.0 87.0 77.0 79.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 88.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 60.0 88.0 
# Forward fill and set axis to rows (compare with previous example)
df.fillna(method='ffill', axis=1)
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 83.0 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 63 87.0 77.0 77.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 60.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 82.0 82.0 
# Set value to a dictionary of values (unique replacement value for each column)
values = {'A':222, 'B':333, 'C':444, 'D':555, 'F':666}
df.fillna(value=values)
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 444.0 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 333.0 87.0 77.0 666.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 666.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 555.0 666.0 
# Set limit to 1 with no method to fill only the first missing value
df.fillna(value = values, limit=1)
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 444.0 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 333.0 87.0 77.0 666.0
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 555.0 NaN

Transforming Data


Sorting DataFrame Values

The two methods covered in this section, .sort_values() and .sort_index(), allow for efficient sorting of the Pandas DataFrame data structure.

DataFrame.sort_values(by, axis=0, ascending=True, inplace=False, kind='quicksort', na_position='last', ignore_index='False', key=None)

  • by (string or list of strings): Name or list of names to sort by
    • 0 or 'index': by may contain index levels and/or column labels
    • 1 or 'columns': by may contain column levels and/or index labels
  • axis(0/'index' or 1/'columns'): axis to be sorted
  • ascending (bool or list of bools), default True: If True sort values in ascending order, if False sort in descending order
  • inplace (bool): if True perform the operation in-place
  • kind ('quicksort', 'mergesort', 'heapsort', 'stable'): sorting algorithm used (see numpy.sort() for details)
  • na_position ('first' or 'last'): argument specifying where NaNs should appear
  • ignore_index (bool): If True the result axis will be labeled 0, 1, ..., n-1
  • key (callable): when passed in the key function is applied to the series values before sorting
# Example DataFrame
df
name A B C D F
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN 
# Default Sorting Options - Sort by Column A
df.sort_values(by='A')
name A B C D F
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN 
# Sort in descending order and ignore index
df.sort_values(by='A', ascending=False, ignore_index=True)
name A B C D F
0 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN
1 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0
2 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN
3 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0
4 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN 
# Sort by multiple columns - Sorting occurs in order listed
# Sort ascending can be set for each item in list passed to by
df.sort_values(by=['name', 'A'], ascending=[True, False], ignore_index=True)
name A B C D F

DataFrame.sort_index(axis=0, level=None, ascending=True, inplace=False, kind='quicksort', na_position='last', sort_remaining=True, ignore_index='False', key=None)

  • axis(0/'index' or 1/'columns'): axis to be sorted
  • level (int or level name or lists of ints or names): sort on values in specified index level(s) when not None
  • ascending (bool or list of bools): If True sort values in ascending order, if False sort in descending order
  • inplace (bool): if True perform the operation in-place
  • kind ('quicksort', 'mergesort', 'heapsort', 'stable'): sorting algorithm used (see numpy.sort() for details)
  • na_position ('first' or 'last'): argument specifying where NaNs should appear
  • sort_remaining (boo): when True and sorting by level and index is multilevel, sort by other level as well, in order, after sorting by specified level
  • ignore_index (bool): if True the result axis will be labeled 0, 1, ..., n-1
  • key (callable): when passed in the key function is applied to the series values before sorting

Add Columns / Rows

Add Columns to a DataFrame

Pandas offers a number of methods for adding columns of data to a DataFrame. The values of the new column can be given as an array or list of the same size as the DataFrame and then assigned to the new column by providing the name.

This is a common approach when the new column can be added to the end of the DataFrame (i.e. the last column)

df['E'] = [89, 77, 96, 83, 72]
df
A B C D F G E
group name
1 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 79.0 a 89
John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 NaN B 77
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 88.0 C 96
Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 NaN d 83
1 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN NaN E 72

DataFrame.insert(loc, column, value, allow_duplicates=False)
A method that provides the flexibility to add a column in any position as well as providing options for inserting the column values

  • loc (int): the insertion index, must be greater than or equal to 0 and less than or equal to the length of the DataFrame
  • column (string, number, or hashable object): label of the inserted column
  • value (scalar, series, or array-like): the values to be inserted
  • allow_duplicates (bool): boolean value indicating whether to allow duplicates or not
# Drop E added in previous example
df.drop(columns=['E'], inplace=True)

# Insert E in proper location
e_values = [89, 77, np.nan, 83, 72]
df.insert(4, 'E', e_values)
df
A B C D E F G
group name

John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 77.0 NaN B
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 NaN 88.0 C
Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 83.0 NaN d
1 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.0 NaN E

DataFrame.assign(**kwargs)
A method that assigns new columns to a DataFrame and returns a new object with the original columns in addition to the newly defined columns.

  • **kwargs (dict of {str: callable or Series}): The column names are the key words of the dictionary
    • If values are callable, pandas will compute on the DataFrame and assign to the new columns

Multiple columns can be assigned using .assign() and later items in **kwargs can reference previously created new columns (i.e. items are computed/assigned in order)

df.assign(mean=df.mean(axis=1))

df.assign(H=[65, 55, 56, 62, 68], h=lambda x: x['H'] + 10)

Add Rows to a DataFrame

DataFrame.loc[]
The .loc[] property allows access to a group of rows or columns and can be utilized to add rows to a DataFrame

For more details and examples of selecting and subsetting a DataFrame see the article Pandas: Indexing and Slicing

pandas.concat(objs, axis=0, join='outer', ignore_index=False, keys=None, levels=None, names=None, verify_integrity=False, sort=False, copy=True)

A function that provides the ability to concatenate pandas objects along a particular axis with optional set logic along the other axes

  • objs (sequence or mapping of Series or DataFrame objects): If mapping is passed, the sorted keys will be used as the keys argument unless it is passed in.
  • axis (0/'index' or 1/'columns'): the axis to concatenate along
  • join ('inner', 'outer'): how to handle indexes on other axes
  • ignore_index (bool): If True do not use the index value along the concatenation axis, typically helpful when the concatenation axis does not have meaningful indexing information
  • keys (sequence): when multiples levels are passed in they should contain tuples, hierarchical indexes are constructed using the passed keys as the outermost level
  • levels (list of sequences): unique values to use for constructing a multi-index
  • names (list): names for the levels in the hierarchical index
  • verify_integrity (bool): If True pandas will check whether the new concatenated axis contains duplicates
  • sort (bool): sort non-concatenation axis if it is not aligned when join is 'outer'.
  • copy (bool): If False data is not copied unnecessarily

For more joining operations see Joining DataFrames

Remove Columns / Rows

.drop() is a method which removes rows or columns by providing label names and the corresponding axis or by specifying the index or column names.

DataFrame.drop(labels=None, axis=0, index=None, columns=None, level=None, inplace=False, errors='raise')

  • labels (single label or list-like): the index or column label to drop
  • axis (0/'index' or 1/'column'): drop labels from the index or columns
  • index (single label or list-like): can be used as an alternative to specifying the axis parameter
    • .drop(labels, axis=0) is equivalent to .drop(index=labels)
  • columns (single label or list-list): can be used as an alternative to specifying the axis parameter
    • .drop(labels, axis=1) is equivalent to .drop(columns=labels)
  • level (int or level name): the level from which the labels will be removed
  • inplace (bool): if True the drop operation occurs in place .drop() returns None otherwise a copy of the DataFrame is returned
  • errors ('ignore', 'raise'): if 'ignore' errors will be suppressed and only existing labels are dropped from the DataFrame

Aggregating DataFrames

An essential step to gaining insights into a dataset is the ability to effectively summarize the data. Pandas offers a variety of methods ranging from simple calculations (e.g. .sum()) to more complex operations using groupby

Descriptive Statistics

Descriptive statistics are operations that summarize the central tendency, dispersion, and shape of a dataset

Basic summary methods include .count(), .sum(), .mode(), .min(), max(), .var(), .std(), .mean(), .quantile(), .median()

DataFrame.sum()
DataFrame.mean()
DataFrame.median()
DataFrame.min()
DataFrame.max()
A few general parameters explored here include

  • axis(0, 1): specify the axis (index or columns) the function should be applied on
  • skipna (bool): if True exclude null values when computing
  • level (int or level name): if the axis is hierarchical, count along a specified level, collapsing into a scalar
  • numeric_only (bool): includes only float, int, and boolean columns, when None (default) pandas attempts to use everything then only numeric data
  • **kwargs: any additional keyword arguments
  • min_count (int): specify the required number of valid value needed to perform the operation
    • parameter for .sum()
# Example DataFrame
df.reset_index(inplace=True)
df.drop(columns=['grouping'], inplace=True)
df

Method: .describe()

A helpful method for generating descriptive statistics is .describe()
DataFrame.describe(percentiles=None, include=None, exclude=None, datatime_is_numeric=False)

  • percentiles (list-like): the percentiles to include in the output, and should be between 0 and 1, default = [.25, .5, .75]
  • include ('all', list-like, or None): list of data types to include in the result
  • exclude (list-like of dtypes or None): data types to omit from the result
  • datetime_is_numeric (bool): boolean value indicating whether datetime data types should be treated as numeric
df.describe()

Method: .agg()

The .agg() (alias of .aggregate()) method aggregates values using one or more operations over a specified axis.
DataFrame.agg(func=None, axis=0, *args, **kwargs)

  • func (function, str, list, or dict): the function(s) to be used for aggregating the data
  • axis (0/'index', 1/'columns'): the axis the operation is performed on
    • 'index': the function is applied to each column
    • 'columns': the function is applied to each row
  • *args: positional arguments passed to func
  • **kwargs: keyword arguments passed to func
# Remove the name column and calculate column sum, mean, and max
df.drop('name',axis=1).agg(['sum', 'mean', 'max'])
A B C D E F
sum 481.000000 350.0 433.0 375.0 418.0 252.0
mean 80.166667 87.5 86.6 75.0 83.6 84.0
max 98.000000 99.0 93.0 88.0 97.0 88.0

Pandas offers many other computation and descriptive statistic methods. For more information and example see the Pandas Documentation



Grouped Summary Statistics

The basic descriptive statistics can provide quick insights into the dataset, however to conditionally aggregate by a label or index requires the use of the groupby operation.

The groupby operation can be thought of as consisting of three stages:

  • Split: the breaking up and grouping of the DataFrame
  • Apply: computing the desired operation(s) for each group
  • Combine: merge the results of the of the operation(s)

When using the .groupby() method these steps are not explicit providing relief from considering how the computation is done and focusing on the operation as a whole

DataFrame.groupby(by=None, axis=0, level=None, as_index=True, sort=True, group_key=True, squeeze=NoDefault.no_default, observed=False, dropna=True)

Parameters explored here include:

  • by (mapping, function, label, or list of labels): determines the grouping
  • level (int, level name, sequence of level names): specify a particular level(s) to group by if the axis hierarchical
  • dropna (bool): when True missing values will be dropped, when False missing values will be treated as the key in groups
# Example DataFrame
df['class'] = ['MWF', 'MWF', 'TTH', 'MWF', 'TTH', 'MWF']
df
name A B C D E F class
0 Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 89.0 79.0 MWF
1 John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 77.0 NaN MWF
2 Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 NaN 88.0 TTH
3 Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 83.0 NaN MWF
4 Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.0 NaN TTH
5 Aaron 88 NaN 93.0 72.0 97.0 85.0 MWF 
# Group by Column Value
df.groupby(['class']).mean()

MWF M Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 83.0 NaN
TTH M Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.0 NaN
MWF N Aaron 88 NaN 93.0 72.0 97.0 85.0 
df.groupby(level='time').mean()
A B C D E F
time
M 81.333333 86.333333 80.500000 74.000000 81.333333 79.0
N 79.000000 91.000000 90.666667 75.666667 87.000000 86.5 
df.groupby(level=0).mean()
A B C D E F
class
MWF 80.0 91.0 86.333333 74.25 86.5 82.0
TTH 80.5 84.0 87.000000 78.00 72.0 88.0 
# Handling missing values in the by column
df.reset_index(inplace=True)
df['class']=['MWF', None, None, 'MWF', 'TTH', 'MWF']
df
class time name A B C D E F
0 MWF M Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 89.0 79.0
1 None N John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 77.0 NaN
2 None N Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 NaN 88.0
3 MWF M Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 83.0 NaN
4 TTH M Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.0 NaN
5 MWF N Aaron 88 NaN 93.0 72.0 97.0 85.0 
df.groupby(by='class').mean()
A B C D E F
class
MWF 85.666667 91.0 86.0 73.333333 89.666667 82.0
TTH 75.000000 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.000000 NaN 
df.groupby(by='class', dropna=False).mean()
A B C D E F
class
MWF 85.666667 91.0 86.0 73.333333 89.666667 82.0
TTH 75.000000 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.000000 NaN
NaN 74.500000 91.0 89.5 77.500000 77.000000 88.0

Pivot Table

Similar to .groupby the .pivot_table() method provide a multidimensional summary of the dataset. While .groupby splits/combines data across a 1D index, pivot_table splits/combines the data across a 2D grid.

pandas.pivot_table(values=None, index=None, columns=None, aggfunc='mean', fill_value=None, margins=False, dropna=True, margins_name='All', observed=False, sort=True)

Parameters explored here include:

  • values: the columns to aggregate - the column to summarize
  • index (column, Grouper, array, or a list of them): what to group by columns. If an array, it must be the same length as the DataFrame
  • columns (column, Grouper, array, or list of them): If an array, it must be the same length as the DataFrame
  • aggfunc (function, list of functions, dict): if a list of functions the pivot table will contain a hierarchical column whose top level will be the function names, if a dict is passed the key is the column to summarize and value is the function or list of functions
  • fill_value (scalar): specify a value to replace missing values in the resulting pivot table
# Example DataFrame
df['group'] = ['group1', 'group2', 'group1', 'group2', 'group2', 'group2']
df
class time name A B C D E F group
0 MWF M Oliver 71 83.0 NaN 88.0 89.0 79.0 group1
1 None N John 63 NaN 87.0 77.0 77.0 NaN group2
2 None N Jane 86 91.0 92.0 78.0 NaN 88.0 group1
3 MWF M Ashley 98 99.0 79.0 60.0 83.0 NaN group2
4 TTH M Steve 75 77.0 82.0 NaN 72.0 NaN group2
5 MWF N Aaron 88 NaN 93.0 72.0 97.0 85.0 group2 
df.pivot_table(values='A', 
                index=['class'])
A
class
MWF 85.666667
TTH 75.000000 
# Pass a list to the index parameter
df.pivot_table(values='A', 
                index=['class', 'time'])
A
class time
MWF M 84.5
N 88.0
TTH M 75.0 
# Include the summarization of multiple columns
df.pivot_table(values=['A', 'B'], 
                index=['class', 'time'])
A B
class time
MWF M 84.5 91.0
N 88.0 NaN
TTH M 75.0 77.0 
# Pass a list of functions to aggfunc
df.pivot_table(values=['A', 'B'], 
                index=['class', 'time'], 
                aggfunc=[np.min, np.max])
amin amax
A B A B
class time
MWF M 71 83.0 98 99.0
N 88 NaN 88 NaN
TTH M 75 77.0 75 77.0 
# Pivot on two variables - provide a column name to column
df.pivot_table(values=['A', 'B'], 
                index=['class', 'time'], 
                aggfunc=[np.min, np.max], 
                columns='group')
amin amax
A B A B
group group1 group2 group1 group2 group1 group2 group1 group2
class time
MWF M 71.0 98.0 83.0 99.0 71.0 98.0 83.0 99.0
N NaN 88.0 NaN NaN NaN 88.0 NaN NaN
TTH M NaN 75.0 NaN 77.0 NaN 75.0 NaN 77.0 
# Specify a fill value for NaN in pivot table
df.pivot_table(values=['A', 'B'], 
                index=['class', 'time'], 
                aggfunc=[np.min, np.max], 
                columns='group', 
                fill_value=0.0)
amin amax
A B A B
group group1 group2 group1 group2 group1 group2 group1 group2
class time
MWF M 71 98 83 99 71 98 83 99
N 0 88 0 0 0 88 0 0
TTH M 0 75 0 77 0 75 0 77


Joining DataFrames

A key feature offered by Pandas is the ability to conduct in-memory join and merge operations. This feature is implemented through the pd.merge() function and the related .join() method of Series and DataFrame objects.

The pd.merge() function implements 3 types of joins

  • one-to-one: every row in the left table is related to one and only one row in the right table
  • many-to-one: every row in the left table is related to one or more rows in the right table
  • many-to-many: multiple rows in the left table is related to multiple rows in the right table

All three are performed with the same call to the function pd.merge() and the type of join performed is dependent on the form of the input data

If both key columns contain rows where the key is a null value these rows will be matched - this is different behavior than the usual SQL join behavior

pandas.merge() is a function that can be used to perform database-style joins on Series and DataFrame objects.

pandas.merge(left, right, how='inner', on=None, left_on=None, right_on=None, left_index=False, right_index=False, sort=False, suffixes=('_x', '_y'), copy=True, indicator=False, validate=None)

  • left: DataFrame
  • right: DataFrame or named Series
  • how ('left', 'right', 'outer', 'inner', 'cross'): the type of join to perform
  • on (label or list): column or index level names to join on, must be found in both DataFrames.
  • left_on (label or list, or array-like): column or index level names to join on in the left DataFrame
  • right_on (label or list, or array-like): column or index level names to join on in the right DataFrame
  • left_index (bool): use the index from the left DataFrame as the join key(s)
  • right_index (bool): use the index from the right `DataFrame as the join key(s)
  • sort (bool): sort the join key in the resulting DataFrame
  • suffixes (list-like): a length-2 sequence with each element indicating the suffix to add to overlapping column names in the left and right DataFrames. None can be passed in for either the right or left to leave the corresponding column name as-is.
  • copy (bool): if False avoid copy when possible
  • indicator (bool or str): if True add a column to the resulting DataFrame called _merged containing information on the source of each row.
  • validate (str): if specified checks if the merge is of the specified type ("one_to_one", "one_to_many", or "many_to_one")

DataFrame.merge() is a method that can be called on a DataFrame object and provides the same join functionality with similar arguments. Using this method only the right DataFrame has to be specified.

# Example DataFrames
df1 = pd.DataFrame({
    'id':['AAA', 'BBB'],
    'value': ['A1', 'B1']
})
df2 = pd.DataFrame({
    'id':['AAA', 'BBB'],
    'value': ['A2', 'B2']
})
print(f'df1:\n{df1}')
print(f'df2:\n{df2}')

df1:
    id value
0  AAA    A1
1  BBB    B1
df2:
    id value
0  AAA    A2
1  BBB    B2

# Basic Merge - on column with same name
pd.merge(df1, df2, on='id')
id value_x value_y
0 AAA A1 A2
1 BBB B1 B2 
# Basic Merge - using DataFrame.merge()
df1.merge(df2, on='id')
id value_x value_y
0 AAA A1 A2
1 BBB B1 B2 
df1.rename(columns={'id':'left_id'}, inplace=True)
df2.rename(columns={'id':'right_id'}, inplace=True)

# Merge with different column names
df1.merge(df2, 
            left_on='left_id', 
            right_on='right_id')
left_id value_x right_id value_y
0 AAA A1 AAA A2
1 BBB B1 BBB B2 
# Specify suffixes appended to overlapping columns (i.e value)
df1.merge(df2, 
            left_on='left_id', 
            right_on='right_id',
            suffixes=('_left', '_right'))
left_id value_left right_id value_right
0 AAA A1 AAA A2
1 BBB B1 BBB B2 
# Specify suffixes appended to overlapping columns (i.e value)
# Leave left DataFrame column as-is
df1.merge(df2, 
            left_on='left_id', 
            right_on='right_id',
            suffixes=(None, '_right'))
left_id value right_id value_right
0 AAA A1 AAA A2
1 BBB B1 BBB B2 
# Example DataFrame 3
df3 = pd.DataFrame({
    'right_id':['BBB', 'CCC'],
    'value': ['B3', 'C3']
})
print(f'd3:\n{df3}')

d3:
  right_id value
0      BBB    B3
1      CCC    C3

# Join Type - Inner
df1.merge(df3, 
            left_on='left_id', 
            right_on='right_id', 
            how='inner')
left_id value_x right_id value_y
0 BBB B1 BBB B3 
# Join Type - Left
df1.merge(df3, 
            left_on='left_id', 
            right_on='right_id', 
            how='left')
left_id value_x right_id value_y
0 AAA A1 NaN NaN
1 BBB B1 BBB B3 
# Join Type - Outer
df1.merge(df3, 
            left_on='left_id', 
            right_on='right_id', 
            how='outer')
left_id value_x right_id value_y
0 AAA A1 NaN NaN
1 BBB B1 BBB B3
2 NaN NaN CCC C3

The related DataFrame.join() method provides similar functionality as .merge() when joining a DataFrame to another DataFrame either on the index or a key column.

DataFrame.join(other, on=None, how='left', lsuffix='', rsuffix='', sort=False)

For additional information and examples please see the Pandas Documentation here: pandas.DataFrame.join()



If you enjoy what you read and find it helpful please check back, and check back often. Follow me on Medium while giving a clap to the article! Also don't forget to subscribe to the INQUISITIVE NATURE publication.

entry.title: Bitcoin Portfolio Analysis
entry.content:
Bitcoin Investment Report

1.0 Executive Summary

Bitcoin and the larger cryptocurrency landscape has gained the attention of investors. However, due to how recent this landscape is and how fast changing it is, a major consideration has to be whether historic returns represent good long term investments.

As access to cryptocurrency wallets and trading apps has increased so has the breadth of the audience interested in Bitcoin and investments in cryptocurrency. From an investing standpoint the questions addressed here is whether the inclusion of Bitcoin improves a portfolios performance.

For the analysis of Bitcoin, the historic prices of Bitcoin, the S&P 500 and gold since 2014 were utilized. The main objectives of the analysis are:

  • How does the historic performance of Bitcoin compare to the S&P 500 and the price of gold?
  • How does the inclusion of Bitcoin impact a portfolios characteristics (e.g. risk and return), and can it improve the performance?
  • What is the potential to utilize Bitcoin as a hedge against inflation?
  • The goal of the portfolio of interest is to minimize risk: what is the allocation of the three assets classes that produced the minimum volatility portfolio? What portfolio maximized the risk-adjusted returns?

This analysis showed that the historic performance of Bitcoin significantly outperformed the S&P 500 and the price of gold. However, this strong performance came with significantly higher risk. The primary consideration of this analysis was to provide an allocation recommendation of Bitcoin as part of a 3 asset portfolio (Bitcoin, S&P 500, and Gold). Optimization of various portfolios indicated that if the primary requirement is to minimize risk there likely is no place for Bitcoin in the portfolio. However, not including Bitcoin would not take advantage of the strong performance Bitcoin experienced and a small allocation of Bitcoin was shown to be beneficial to portfolio performance while not significantly increase the risk portfolio.

Note: This analysis was conducted for purely demonstrative purposes and should not be viewed as investment advice. The analysis within this report focuses solely on historic performance, which can aid in addressing the above questions, but should not be extrapolated into the future. A few factors that could impact the findings are due to the relatively short period of the analysis window, the relatively low inflation rate during this period, and the transition of Bitcoin to becoming mainstream. These factors may differ significantly in the future.

2.0 Environment Setup

2.1 Library Import

# Import Python Libraries
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
from scipy import stats

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.ticker import PercentFormatter
import matplotlib.ticker as mtick
import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime
from datetime import timedelta

from pypfopt.efficient_frontier import EfficientFrontier

%matplotlib inline

3.0 Data Description & Cleaning

The Bitcoin and S&P 500 datasets consist of daily observations ranging from Sept. 17th 2014 to Nov. 17th 2021, and Sept. 17th 2014 to Nov. 15th 2021, respectively. The Bitcoin dataset contains 2619 records with 4 missing data points, and the S&P 500 dataset contains 1805 records with no missing data points.

The price of gold and US inflation consists of monthly observations covering Sept. 1st 2014 to Nov. 1st 2021. An important not on the monthly dataset is that the CPI value refers to the previous month's inflation index, and the price of gold is provided for on the first day of the month (i.e. the current month value).

3.1 Bitcoin daily data in US dollars

# Read in data
bitcoin = pd.read_csv('./data/bitcoin-usd.csv'
                        , parse_dates=['date']
                        , index_col='date')

3.1.1 Data Descriptions

  • "date" - date from September 17, 2014 to November 17, 2021
  • "open" - the price at the beginning of the trading day
  • "high" - the highest price reached that day
  • "low" - the lowest price reached that day
  • "close" - the price at the closing of the trading day
  • "volume" - how many Bitcoin were traded that day

3.2 S&P 500 daily data

sp500 = pd.read_csv('./data/sp500.csv'
                    , parse_dates=['date']
                    , index_col='date')

3.2.1 Data Descriptions

  • "date" - date from September 17, 2014 to November 17, 2021
  • "open" - the index level at the beginning of the trading day
  • "high" - the highest level reached that day
  • "low" - the lowest level reached that day
  • "close" - the level at the closing of the trading day
  • "volume" - how many shares in the companies that make up the index were traded that day

3.3 Inflation and gold as monthly data

monthly_data = pd.read_csv('./data/monthly_data.csv'
                            , parse_dates=['date']
                            , index_col='date')

3.3.1 Data Descriptions

  • "date" - date from September, 2014 to November, 2021
  • "gold_usd" - price in usd of gold for that month
  • "cpi_us" - the inflation index for the US for that month (cpi = consumer price index)

CPI data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. Publicly available information.

3.4 Data Cleaning

3.4.1 Drop Bitcoin missing records

bitcoin = bitcoin.dropna(subset=['close'])

3.4.2 Resample Bitcoin and S&P 500 Data

For most of this analysis the monthly resampled values will be utilized due to the price of gold and inflation index only have a monthly frequency. Provided the observation period of approximately 7 years (2014-2021), a monthly frequency should be adequate for portfolio asset allocations determinations.

monthly_btc = bitcoin.resample('MS').last()
monthly_sp500 = sp500.resample('MS').last()

3.4.3 Renaming Columns

A majority of this analysis will focus around the closing price for Bitcoin and S&P 500 (i.e. close column in dataset) and the price of gold (i.e. gold_usd in the dataset). For ease of analysis these columns will all be renamed price_usd.

monthly_btc.rename(columns={'close':'price_usd'}, inplace=True)
monthly_sp500.rename(columns={'close':'price_usd'}, inplace=True)
monthly_data.rename(columns={'gold_usd':'price_usd'}, inplace=True)

3.4.4 Reference Dataframe

# Create Reference DataFrame
dataframe_dict = {}
# List of dataframe names 
dataset_names = ['monthly_btc', 'monthly_sp500', 'gold_inf']

# Imported raw datasets
dataframe_dict['raw_data'] = {
    'bitcoin':bitcoin,
    'sp500':sp500,
    'monthly_data':monthly_data
}

# Monthly Resampled datasets for analysis
dataframe_dict['monthly_data'] = {
    'monthly_btc': monthly_btc,
    'monthly_sp500': monthly_sp500,
    'gold_inf':monthly_data
}

# Colors for plotting
dataframe_dict['colors'] = {
    'blue':'#4C72B0', 
    'green':'#55A868', 
    'red':'#C44E52'
}

4.0 Exploratory Data Analysis

4.1 Price and Return Analysis

#Calculate the cumulative return
dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc']['creturn'] = (1 + dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc']['price_usd'].pct_change()).cumprod()
dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500']['creturn'] = (1 + dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500']['price_usd'].pct_change()).cumprod()
dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf']['creturn'] = (1 + dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf']['price_usd'].pct_change()).cumprod()

#Plot Development
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(15,6))
fig.suptitle("Figure 1: Asset Class Price & Cumulative Returns", weight='bold')
rows = 3
columns = 2

grid = plt.GridSpec(rows, columns, wspace=0.25, hspace=0.25)

list_of_colors = ['blue', 'green', 'red']
labels = ['Bitcoin Close Price', 'S&P 500 Close Price', 'Gold Price']

#Iterate over each assets dataframe
for i in range(len(dataframe_dict['monthly_data'])):
    key = dataset_names[i]
    #Construct column 1 (left) subplots
    plot = plt.subplot(grid[i, 0])
    plt.plot(dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][key].index, 
        dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][key]['price_usd'], 
        color=dataframe_dict['colors'][list_of_colors[i]])
    
    plt.legend(labels=[labels[i]])
    plt.ylabel(labels[i])
    if i == 0 : plot.set_title('Figure 1a: Asset Class Closing Price')

    #Construct Column 2 (right) single plot 
    creturn_plot = plt.subplot(grid[0:3, 1])
    plt.plot(dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][key].index, 
        dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][key]['creturn'], 
        color=dataframe_dict['colors'][list_of_colors[i]])
    creturn_plot.set(yscale='log')
    creturn_plot.grid(True, which='both')
    creturn_plot.set_title('Figure 1b: Asset Class Cumulative Returns')
    plt.legend(labels=['Bitcoin', 'S&P 500', 'Gold'])

Figure 1a and b shows that the price of Bitcoin increases significantly more than both the S&P 500 and the price of gold during the analysis period. During the analysis period ranging from Sept. 2014 to November 2021 the price of Bitcoin has increased approximately by a factor of 155x, as compared to the S&P 500 and the price of gold experiencing increases of 2.3x and 1.4x, respectively. Note the difference in the scale for Figure 1a and that Figure 1b has a log scale on the vertical axis.

#Calculate the Monthly and Annual Performance for each asset class
bitcoin_performance = (dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc'].price_usd[-1] / dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc'].price_usd[0]) - 1
bitcoin_ann_performance = (bitcoin_performance + 1) ** (1 / (len(dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc']) / 12)) - 1

sp500_performance = (dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500'].price_usd[-1] / dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500'].price_usd[0]) - 1
sp500_ann_performance = (sp500_performance + 1) ** (1 / (len(dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500']) / 12)) - 1 

gold_performance = (dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf'].price_usd[-1] / dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf'].price_usd[0]) - 1
gold_ann_performance = (gold_performance + 1) ** (1 / (len(dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf']) / 12)) - 1

#Construct Summary Stat Dataframe/Table
avg_ann_performance = pd.DataFrame({
    'Average Annual Performance (%)':[round(bitcoin_ann_performance*100,1), round(sp500_ann_performance*100,1), round(gold_ann_performance*100,1)]
}).transpose()
avg_ann_performance.columns = ['Bitcoin', 'S&P 500', 'Gold']

print('Table 1: Average Annual Performance')
display(avg_ann_performance)

Table 1: Average Annual Performance
Bitcoin S&P 500 Gold
Average Annual Performance (%) 100.6 12.7 5.1

Additionally, table 1 shows that Bitcoin (+100.6%) strongly out performed the S&P 500 (+12.5%) as well as gold (+5.1%) during the observation period.

4.2 Daily Trading Volumes - Bitcoin and S&P 500

fig, axes = plt.subplots(figsize=(15,7))
sns.set_style('darkgrid')
daily_data = ['bitcoin', 'sp500']

for i in range(len(dataframe_dict['raw_data'])-1):
    key = daily_data[i]
    plot = sns.lineplot(data=dataframe_dict['raw_data'][key], 
        x='date', 
        y='volume', 
        color=dataframe_dict['colors'][list_of_colors[i]])

plot.set(yscale='log')
plot.set_ylabel('Daily Trading Volume')
plot.set_xlabel('Date')
plot.grid(True, which='both')
plot.set_title('Figure 2. Asset Class Daily Trading Volumes', weight='bold')
plt.legend(labels=['Bitcoin', 'S&P 500'])

<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x7f18f40864f0>

Figure 2 highlights a potential analysis period bias impacting the findings and the analysis of Bitcoin. The analysis period begins in late 2014 through late 2021, also during this period the significant increase in trading volumes observed with Bitcoin are indicative of its transition to mainstream. During this same period it can be observed that the trading volume of the S&P 500 remained relatively stable. It should be noted that the trading volumes and the sharp increase in the trading volume may warrant further investigated prior to using in additionally analysis. Additionally, the Bitcoin trend observed 2014 - 2021 has a high potential of not remaining moving into the future now that Bitcoin has become mainstream rather than emerging and transitioning to mainstream.

5.0 Asset Class Risk and Return

5.1 Annual Returns

annual_data = {
    'annual_btc': {},
    'annual_sp500': {},
    'annual_gold': {}
}

annual_dfs = list(annual_data.keys())

#Populate the annual dataframe of dataframes
for i in range(len(dataframe_dict['monthly_data'])):
    key = dataset_names[i]
    monthly_df = dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][key]
    annual = monthly_df.resample('Y').last()
    annual['pct_change'] = annual.price_usd.pct_change()
    annual.drop(annual.index[0], inplace=True)
    annual_data[annual_dfs[i]] = annual

dataframe_dict['annual_data'] = annual_data

#Append the asset class column used in Figure there to color each differently
annual_append = pd.DataFrame()

for df in dataframe_dict['annual_data']:
    dataframe_dict['annual_data'][df][['asset_class']] = df[df.find("_") + 1:]
    dataframe_dict['annual_data'][df][['pct_change', 'asset_class']]
    annual_append = pd.concat([
        annual_append, dataframe_dict['annual_data'][df][['pct_change', 'asset_class']]
        ])

fig, axes = plt.subplots(figsize=(15,7))
sns.set_style('darkgrid')

plot = sns.barplot(data=annual_append, x=annual_append.index.year, y='pct_change', hue='asset_class', palette=['#4C72B0','#55A868','#C44E52'])
plot.axes.yaxis.set_major_formatter(mtick.PercentFormatter(1))
plot.set_ylim([-1, 2])
plot.set_ylabel('Total Return')
plot.set_xlabel('Year (Jan 2015 - Oct 2021')
plot.annotate("1369%", (1.6, 2), color='#4C72B0', fontweight='bold')
plot.annotate("303%", (4.62, 2), color='#4C72B0', fontweight='bold')
plot.set_title('Figure 3. Asset Class Return by Year', weight='bold', pad=15)

Text(0.5, 1.0, 'Figure 3. Asset Class Return by Year')

Figure 3 shows that Bitcoin has significantly outperformed both the S&P 500 and the price of Gold for all years within the analysis period, with the exception of 2018. During this period Bitcoin has the largest positive annual returns by a large margin with two years of note (i.e. 2017 and 2020), however in 2018 when all asset classes experience a negative annual return Bitcoin also had the largest loss highlighting the volatility Bitcoin experiences. Additional analysis will be conducted to first look at the monthly returns distributions to provide additional insight on the behavior, and then also further examine asset class volatility.

for df in dataframe_dict['monthly_data']:
    dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][df]['pct_change'] = dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][df]['price_usd'].pct_change()

fig, axes = plt.subplots(1,4, figsize=(25,5), sharey=True)

titles = ['Bitcoin', 'S&P 500', 'Gold']

for i in range(len(dataframe_dict['monthly_data'])):
    key = dataset_names[i]
    plot = sns.histplot(
        data=dataframe_dict['monthly_data'][key], 
        x='pct_change', ax=axes[i], 
        bins=20, 
        kde=True, 
        color=dataframe_dict['colors'][list_of_colors[i]])
    axes[i].set_title(titles[i])
    axes[i].set_xlabel("Monthly Returns")
    plot.axes.xaxis.set_major_formatter(mtick.PercentFormatter(1))

plot = sns.histplot(data=dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc'], x ='pct_change', color='#4C72B0', alpha=0.25, ax=axes[3], bins=20, element='step')
plot = sns.histplot(data=dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500'], x='pct_change', color='#55A868', alpha = 0.25, ax=axes[3], bins=20, element='step')
plot = sns.histplot(data=dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf'], x='pct_change', color='#C44E52', alpha = 0.25, ax=axes[3], bins=20, element='step')
plot.axes.xaxis.set_major_formatter(mtick.PercentFormatter(1))
plot.axes.set_title('All Asset Classes')
plt.suptitle('Figure 4. Distribution of Monthly Returns', weight='bold')

Text(0.5, 0.98, 'Figure 4. Distribution of Monthly Returns')

Figure 4 shows the distribution of monthly returns for each asset class individually and plotted together. It can be seen from Figure 4 that the range in monthly returns for Bitcoin is much larger than than for the S&P 500 and the gold during the analysis period.

The distributions for the S&P 500 and gold appear to be near normal distributions centered at approximately zero, slightly positive for the S&P 500. The distribution of the S&P 500 monthly returns has a slight negative skew indicating returns are likely to have many small positive gains and few large losses. The distribution of Bitcoin monthly returns is a much flatter distribution consisting of fatter positive and negative tails and a positive skew. The Bitcoin distribution indicates that the variance in returns (positive and negative) is due to frequent extreme deviations from the mean.

5.2 Drawdown Analysis

def drawdown_calc(prices):
    expanding_max = prices.expanding().max()
    daily_drawdown = (prices / expanding_max) - 1
    max_daily_drawdown = daily_drawdown.cummin()
    return daily_drawdown, max_daily_drawdown

#Calculate Standard Deviation of Returns
btc_ann_std = dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_btc']['pct_change'].std() * (12 ** 0.5)
sp500_ann_std = dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['monthly_sp500']['pct_change'].std() * (12 ** 0.5)
gold_ann_std = dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf']['pct_change'].std() * (12 ** 0.5)

#Calculate Sharpe Ratios
btc_sharpe = bitcoin_ann_performance / btc_ann_std
sp500_sharpe = sp500_ann_performance / sp500_ann_std
gold_sharpe = gold_ann_performance / gold_ann_std

gold_var = dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf']['pct_change'].nsmallest(5)[4]

#Calculate CVaR(5%)

gold_cvar = dataframe_dict['monthly_data']['gold_inf']['pct_change'].nsmallest(4).mean()

Figure 4 and Table 2 show that the significantly higher returns Bitcoin experienced during the analysis period also come with significantly higher risks. The annualized volatility, calculated from the monthly resampled data, was 79.5% for Bitcoin compared to 14.3%, and 12.5% for the S&P 500 and gold, respectively. The maximum drawdown over the analysis period for Bitcoin was -83.4% compared to -33.9% for the S&P 500 calculated from the daily data of both asset classes. The drawdown plots show that relative to the S&P 500 Bitcoin experiences more frequent and more extreme drawdowns throughout the analysis period. It also indicates that recovery from some of the drawdowns can extend several months to more than a year, whereas the recoveries for the S&P 500 are less extreme and the recovery periods typically shorter.

The Sharpe ratio can be used to evaluate the risk-adjusted returns, and the ratio is a measure of excess return over a risk-free alternative. A Sharpe ratio of 1.0 indicates that returns of an investment is proportional to the risk of the investments. Bitcoin's Sharpe ratio was calculated to be 1.3 which is more favorable than the S&P 500 at 0.9 and Gold at 0.4. Although Bitcoin comes with significant risk the Sharpe ratio >1 would indicate that the returns experienced during the analysis period outweigh the associated risk.

Utilizing the volatility to measure risk has limitation, including that it incorporates upside volatility. The addition of the historic Value-at-Risk (VaR) for the 95% confidence interval shows that Bitcoin's historic VaR of 27.8% has been 4x that of the S&P 500. The Conditional VaR (CVaR) measures the mean loss below the VaR and provides another indication of Bitcoin's associated risk, -34.2% compared to the S&P 500 with a value of -9.3%. These measure also have limitation which include an assumption of a normal distribution and should be used with caution.

Considering all measures of risk considered here it becomes clear that Bitcoin's significant returns come with significantly higher risk than the other asset classes under evaluation.

Figure 7 displays the relationships between each asset class and inflation monthly percent change and the individual distributions of monthly percent change during the analysis period, and Table 3 displays the correlation coefficients. The US CPI and Bitcoin subplot (bottom left) does not suggest a strong positive or negative relationship, furthermore the correlation coefficient is near zero with a value of 0.03. Both Figure 7 and Table 3 highlight that since 2014 there is no consistent relationship between inflation and the price of Bitcoin, indicating that Bitcoin would not adequately function as a hedge against inflation.

None of the asset classes analyzed have a strong correlation with inflation with Bitcoin, S&P 500, and Gold having correlation coefficients of 0.03, -0.02, and -0.07, respectively. Based on the correlation coefficients the strongest relationship is the positive relation between the S&P 500 and the price of Bitcoin with value of 0.28 (top most subplot). This relationship could impact the diversification properties of a portfolio that includes both of these asset classes because since 2014 they tend to trend in the same direction. This differs from the relationship between the price of Bitcoin and Gold which have a slight negative relation with a correlation coefficient of -0.19, indicating that during the analysis period the price of Bitcoin and the price of Gold typically trended in opposite directions.

7.0 Portfolio Optimization

btc_sp500_corr_coeff = dataframe_dict['corr_matrix'].iloc[0,1]
btc_gold_corr_coeff = dataframe_dict['corr_matrix'].iloc[0,2]
sp500_gold_corr_coeff = dataframe_dict['corr_matrix'].iloc[1,2]

risk_return = {}
risk_weights = {}

np.random.seed(369)

#Generate 2500 Random Portfolio Samples
for i in np.random.uniform(0, 0.99, 2500):
    btc_weight = round (i, 4)
    sp500_weight = np.random.randint(100-btc_weight*100) / 100
    gold_weight = 1 - sp500_weight - btc_weight

    pf_vol = ((sp500_weight**2)*(sp500_ann_std**2) + (btc_weight**2)*(btc_ann_std**2) + (gold_weight**2)*(gold_ann_std**2)
        + (2*btc_weight*sp500_weight*btc_ann_std*sp500_ann_std*btc_sp500_corr_coeff)
        + (2*sp500_weight*gold_weight*sp500_ann_std*gold_ann_std*sp500_gold_corr_coeff)
        + (2*btc_weight*gold_weight*btc_ann_std*gold_ann_std*btc_gold_corr_coeff)) ** (1/2)

    pf_return = btc_weight*bitcoin_ann_performance + sp500_weight*sp500_ann_performance + gold_weight*gold_ann_performance

    risk_return[pf_vol] = pf_return
    risk_weights[pf_vol] = btc_weight, sp500_weight, gold_weight 

#Construct dataframes from random sampling
dataframe_dict['risk_return'] = pd.DataFrame(list(risk_return.items()), columns=['port_vol', 'port_return'])
dataframe_dict['risk_wts'] = pd.DataFrame(list(risk_weights.items()), columns=['port_vol', 'class_weights'])
dataframe_dict['risk_return']['sharpe'] = dataframe_dict['risk_return']['port_return'] / dataframe_dict['risk_return']['port_vol']
dataframe_dict['portfolio'] = dataframe_dict['risk_return'].merge(dataframe_dict['risk_wts'])

#Approximate Min Volatility and Max Sharpe Portfolios using random sampling
